WRITING.TITLE: A rotten way to start convention week for Republicans

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "Convention week got off to a miserable start for Republicans. I don #8217;t just refer to the whiny first appearance by President Trump, who launched a rambling, incoherent and fact-free rant on Monday, wherein he lied by saying #8220;They #8217;re trying to steal the election from Republicans. Just like they did it last time, with spying. #8221; (This is, of course, based on the crazy, false allegation that the Obama administration #8220;spied on him. #8221;) The bad-news avalanche started even before the Republican National Convention roll call #8217;s resembling a hostage video #8212; a far cry from the uplifting video trip around the country put on by the Democrats last week. And, yes, it started before Vice President Pence hilariously promised to #8220;Make America Great Again, again #8221; (because they sure have wrecked things since 2016?). For starters, Trump is deeply unpopular. A new Associated Press-NORC poll shows his approval down to a paltry 35 percent, and approval for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic even worse at 31 percent. While the president repeatedly hypes a phony figure of more than 90 percent approval among Republicans, this poll pegs it at a mediocre 79 percent. Moreover, the poll found that #8220;just 23% think the country is heading in the right direction, while 75% think it #8217;s on the wrong path. . . . The federal government as a whole has also taken a hit with the public, with approval down from 38% in March to 23% now. #8221; For a party banking on a cult of personality, it might want to find a more popular personality. Moreover, the sleaziness of the Trump world is on full display. Last week, former Trump campaign strategist Stephen K. Bannon was arrested on charges of defrauding Americans in connection with a private build-the-wall scheme (Bannon has pleaded not guilty). We then learned of yet another investigation into Trump #8217;s finances. The Post reports that New York Attorney General Letitia James #8220;is investigating whether President Trump #8217;s company misled lenders and taxing authorities by improperly inflating the value of his assets, according to a court filing on Monday. #8221; James #8217;s investigators are looking into #8220;Statements of Financial Condition #8221; that Trump sent to lenders in summarizing his assets and debts and have tried to subpoena Trump #8217;s son Eric Trump, who has refused to show up. More from The Post: #8220; #8216;The Trump Organization has stalled, withheld documents, and instructed witnesses, including Eric Trump, to refuse to answer questions under oath, #8217; James wrote on Twitter. #8216;That #8217;s why we filed a motion to compel the Trump Organization to comply with our lawful subpoenas for documents and testimony. #8217; #8221; Eric Trump is scheduled to speak Tuesday at the Republican convention. The Post reports that implicated in this investigation are three Trump properties: a golf course in Los Angeles, an office building on Wall Street in Manhattan and a country estate known as Seven Springs in Westchester County, N.Y. The charges appear to stem from his former attorney Michael Cohen #8217;s allegations that Trump provided phony evaluations of properties. The Trump Organization #8217;s chief legal officer, Alan Garten, said in a statement that #8220;The Trump Organization has done nothing wrong. #8221; This is separate, presumably, from yet another investigation overseen by New York City District Attorney Cyrus R. Vance Jr. Meanwhile, Trump is increasingly isolated. White House adviser Kellyanne Conway is departing (she says to attend to her family), and a tape of Trump #8217;s sister attesting to Trump #8217;s untrustworthiness and cruelty has emerged. (His niece, Mary Trump, similarly released a tell-all book in an effort to warn Americans not to reelect a narcissistic and toxic personality such as Trump.) More than 20 former Republican officeholders have signaled their support for Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden, while former Arizona senator Jeff Flake, a rock-ribbed Republican, spoke eloquently as to how Trump has trashed conservative ideals and why he now supports Biden: - t was the honor of my life to represent my state, Arizona #8211; in the United States House and Senate for eighteen years as a conservative. I'm here to talk about the future #8211; both of my party, but more importantly, the future of our country: https://t.co/pxBUFqj9jA #8212; Jeff Flake (@JeffFlake) August 24, 2020 One thing Flake did not mention was the deterioration in the GOP #8217;s adherence to supposed #8220;family values. #8221; With the resignation from Liberty University of Jerry Falwell Jr., an early Trump supporter, as the result of a sex scandal, we are once more reminded that the GOP really does not stand for much of anything. To sum up, the Republican Party has dropped any pretense of a policy platform, throwing its lot in with a racist, xenophobic and compulsively dishonest man who creates chaos and dysfunction and is the subject of multiple investigations relating to his finances. Many decent Republicans are abandoning him in favor of his opponent. This is not five-dimensional chess. It #8217;s a multicar pile-up."

WRITING.TITLE: Nikki Haley and Tim Scott don #8217;t deserve any praise from the media

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "Media analysis of the first night of the out-of-body-experience Republican National Convention tended to praise former ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley and Sen. Tim Scott (R-S.C.). This tells us more about the media than their performances, standing as a self-indictment of the media #8217;s addiction to #8220;balance #8221; that drives them to portray Republicans as more sane and decent than they are. Pundits praised Scott and Haley because they did not scream like other speakers, wink at white supremacy or venerate President Trump. Speaking in an inside voice, eschewing racist appeals and declining to slobber over a U.S. president #8212; in such extreme terms that even Kim Jong Un might say, #8220;Tone it down, guys #8221; #8212; do not deserve praise. Indeed, their performances reveal that Scott and Haley, unlike the true believers, might understand Trump is a toxic figure but are willing to enable him and lie on his behalf. Their sanity makes their falsehoods and denials even worse. Haley repeated untrue talking points. She said Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden wants to ban fracking. (He does not.) And her use of the quote from then-U.N. Ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick that "Democrats always blame America first #8221; in foreign policy was blatant nonsense; Democrats blame Russia, unlike Trump, and they blame a president who egregiously violated his oath. You see, Trump is not the same as #8220;America, #8221; which might escape notice in the cult. Haley repeated the lie that the Obama administration sent cash to Iran; instead, it unfroze assets that Iran owned. Trump did not get tough on North Korea, as she claimed; Trump gave its dictator multiple, stomach-turning PR coups while ignoring his human rights atrocities. And while she didn #8217;t call Biden a socialist, she made it sound as if he were a card-carrying member of the cabal of #8220;Pelosi, Sanders and the Squad. #8221; This is blather you would hear on Fox News. It was downright embarrassing when she could not even perform a humble brag for removing the Confederate flag from the South Carolina capitol grounds as governor. #8220;Together we made the hard choices needed to heal, and removed a divisive symbol peacefully and respectfully, #8221; she said. Perhaps she could not explain what that symbol is because Trump and his cult have defended the Confederate flag, a symbol of white supremacy. So what is Haley doing? She knows about Trump #8217;s grotesque record on human rights, his efforts to sabotage NATO and his extortion of Ukraine and Syria (abandoning the Kurds), yet she cheers him on. She cares so little for the principles she espouses that she will enable someone who betrays America and wants to destroy even the sanctity of elections. No one made her show up. Her dishonesty, low regard for the American people #8217;s intelligence and lack of moral spine should not earn her brownie points. It deserves our scorn. Scott #8217;s address was even more galling since he has, at times, criticized Trump #8217;s racism (including Trump #8217;s statement that there were #8220;very fine #8221; people on both sides of the Charlottesville rally) and watched his party deny systemic racism in America and decline to support real police reform. He chose to obscure who was responsible for Trump-abetted calamities. #8220;From a global pandemic, to the deaths of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, 2020 has tested our nation in ways we haven #8217;t seen for decades, #8221; he said. So how did Trump do? Scott seems to pretend the election is not about Trump and Biden, hiding behind principles Trump rejects such as inclusiveness. He also falsely said the tax cuts did not diminish revenue. Adjusted for inflation and growth, they most certainly did. Laughably, Scott argued that Trump had made the economy more inclusive. In 2019, Politico reported: #8220;Income inequality has reached its highest level in at least 50 years, according to new U.S. government data released today, underscoring a key theme for Democratic candidates hoping to unseat President Donald Trump. #8221; Blacks #8217; wealth compared with Whites has gone down, not up. And as Steve Rattner, former car czar in the Obama administration, recently explained in a New York Times op-ed: #8220;By almost every metric, Black Americans have fared far worse than whites, including higher rates of closure of Black-owned businesses. And that #8217;s after struggling under the Trump administration since long before the virus hit #8212; Black median household incomes, which were 66.5 percent of those of white households in 2016, had dropped to 62.4 percent of the level of white households by 2018. #8221; Again, Scott was not forced to appear. Nevertheless, he came to praise a president who tries to scare White suburbanites with the prospect of Blacks moving into their neighborhoods; does not say the name Breonna Taylor or comment on the shooting of Jacob Blake in Kenosha, Wis.; refers to majority-Black nations as #8220;shithole countries, #8221; calls Mexican immigrants #8220;criminals" and "rapists #8221;; encourages China to build detention camps for Uighurs; and betrayed his country by seeking to extort an ally in a war against Russia. What does it say about Scott that he would defend an overt racist and admirer of dictators? It says he either is blinded by the right-wing propaganda machine or, just like Trump, is willing to look Americans in the eye and lie. This, too, is unworthy of praise."
When that black voice lies and denies that Trump is a racist and has racist policies, that voice should be called out. (And criticism is not silencing.)
So any criticism makes me a klan member, even when I'm calling out Trump for overt racism? Give it a rest.

WRITING.TITLE: Whip cracking, drinking and profanity-laced threats: Government office in charge of etiquette plagued by etiquette problems, watchdog finds

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT (shortened for length): "When the United States hosts foreign leaders and dignitaries, a little-known office at the State Department is in charge of sweating every detail, from choreographing presidential handshakes to arranging seating charts to managing dietary restrictions. The Office of the Chief of Protocol oversees the glitz and glamour of diplomacy, and is responsible for enforcing the rules of decorum to maintain tradition and tee up U.S. negotiators for success. But inside that office, U.S. employees have complained about internal breaches in etiquette and protocol under the leadership of the Trump administration #8217;s political appointees running day-to-day affairs. The complaints resulted in an investigation by the State Department #8217;s in-house watchdog, which in May produced a report saying that the former chief of protocol, Sean Lawler, committed what could be considered #8220;workplace violence #8221; and that Cam Henderson, the current chief of protocol, and Mary-Kate Fisher, her deputy, #8220;failed to report #8221; that behavior #8220;in violation of Department policies. #8221; Officials described an environment of yelling, cursing, #8220;overconsuming alcohol, #8221; and intimidating and abusive behavior, according to the report, which was obtained by The Washington Post. #8220;Mr. Lawler had an explosive personality and regularly would throw papers and binders, #8221; the report said of his tenure from December 2017 to July 2019. #8220;Several employees reported that he would crack a horse whip in the office and that, given his general demeanor and conduct, these actions placed them in fear of physical harm. #8221; State Department officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of retaliation, said Lawler routinely made abusive, homophobic and culturally insensitive comments to his subordinates. The leadership of the State Department strongly rejected the findings of the report and questioned the motives of the watchdog, which it says demonstrated a #8220;systemic pattern of selective inclusion and exclusion of facts. #8221; The State Department #8217;s June 30 response, which The Post obtained, is the latest sign of bad blood between Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and the office of the inspector general, which is responsible for investigating suspected waste, fraud and malfeasance at the department. Pompeo orchestrated the ouster of Steve Linick, the department #8217;s previous inspector general, in the spring, but Linick #8217;s investigations are continuing to be pursued by his successors. The leadership #8217;s response was addressed to Linick #8217;s replacement, Stephen Akard, who abruptly resigned this month after less than three months on the job. Akard had been under pressure from Democratic lawmakers to recuse himself from investigations of whether Pompeo and his wife, Susan, inappropriately used federal resources. Pompeo has denied the allegations. Akard was replaced by Diana R. Shaw, his deputy. The watchdog report says it is based on accounts from #8220;numerous #8221; officials and took into account other internal investigations by the Office of Civil Rights and the Bureau of Diplomatic Security. It also notes that some of the abusive incidents were relayed in #8220;general terms #8221; to protect the identity of officials who #8220;expressed a fear of retaliation. #8221; Elements of the document were first reported by Politico earlier this month. When asked about the charges, Lawler told The Post that they were #8220;ridiculously offensive and untrue. #8221; He declined to respond in detail to the various allegations. A State Department spokesperson added that it is #8220;outrageous that a memo on personnel matters which makes unsubstantiated accusations has been leaked to the press. #8221; Public awareness of problems at the Protocol Office emerged in June of last year after Lawler was suspended amid complaints about harassment, including accounts that he carried a whip around the office. The report sheds new light on a variety of unusual events that took place at the Protocol Office. The whip, for instance, was #8220;gifted #8221; to Lawler by a delegation visiting from Kazakhstan, according to the response from Henderson and Fisher, who called it a #8220;riding crop. #8221; #8220;There was a verbal complaint from a staff member about this riding crop, directed to Ms. Henderson, who responded by moving the riding crop into her office for safekeeping and informing Ambassador Lawler he should no longer carry the riding crop on his person for any reason, #8221; the response says. The Protocol Office is home to an influential group of former aides to ex-New Jersey governor Chris Christie (R). Henderson and Fisher worked for Christie, who endorsed Donald Trump at a pivotal moment in the 2016 presidential race. Officials told The Post that Lawler picked on gay employees and made them feel disrespected. Two State Department officials said Lawler referred to one gay subordinate named Kyle as #8220;Kylie. #8221; The officials also noted that Lawler said that a group of visiting Japanese diplomats #8220;looked like gay porn stars #8221; and that he thought he was getting #8220;hit on #8221; and didn #8217;t want their gifts. Officials alleged that Lawler made other offensive comments. After a group of Turkish nationals visited the Protocol Office and offered a gift of dates, according to an official, Lawler said the dates were #8220;disgusting, #8221; just like the #8220;dirty #8221; men who had brought them."

WRITING.TITLE: Don #8217;t want to watch the RNC? You #8217;re in good company.

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "A slew of Democrats, independents and disaffected Republicans have, almost tearfully, taken to social media to plead their case: Do I have to watch the RNC? The answer is no, and you don #8217;t even have to feel guilty about it. Let #8217;s begin with the notion that you should listen to the arguments of your ideological opponents. Well, that is a good idea, but that does not mean one must endure screaming, dog whistles and bullhorn appeals to White supremacy and abjectly ridiculous accusations ( #8220;Joe Biden will destroy the suburbs! #8221; #8220;Biden is a socialist! #8221;). There is no agenda (just defend Trump, the RNC #8217;s platform says); thus, there are no arguments in defense of President Trump #8217;s nonexistent policies. Moreover, you need not endure an hour or more each night of straight bile when responsible news outlets can give you the recap. Moreover, there is something to be said for self-care in the Trump era. We have become numb after four years or so of lies, racism, xenophobia, narcissism and cruelty. You have to wonder if less consumption of President Trump and his cultists would help put his most egregious remarks in perspective. If you ever found yourself at the end of a week #8212; or even a day #8212; experiencing difficulty recalling the third- or fourth-most-recent outrage, you understand how more exposure does not necessarily make you more cognizant of the lying, norm-breaking, meanness and bigotry. The sheer quantity of his lies, outrages and attacks makes it all a blur. (Remember when he commuted Roger Stone #8217;s sentence? That was only last month.) There is a wealth of research out there that frequent exposure to hate speech (what else would you call Trump #8217;s racist appeals and personal attacks?) makes us, as one paper from 2017 put it, #8220;less sensitive to hate speech and more prejudiced toward hate speech victims than their counterparts in the control condition. #8221; Richard A. Friedman, a psychiatrist, wrote in 2018 that #8220;politicians like Mr. Trump who stoke anger and fear in their supporters provoke a surge of stress hormones, like cortisol and norepinephrine, and engage the amygdala, the brain center for threat. #8221; He continued: #8220;One study, for example, that focused on #8216;the processing of danger #8217; showed that threatening language can directly activate the amygdala. This makes it hard for people to dial down their emotions and think before they act. #8221; In layman #8217;s terms: All that anger and fear can make you less rational. And do not worry that you are missing out on what others are absorbing. #8220;The first night of the Republican National Convention averaged 17 million viewers on Monday, a sharp drop of 26% from 2016, #8221; the Los Angeles Times reported. #8220;The audience figure from Nielsen was also below the opening night of last week #8217;s Democratic National Convention, which averaged 19.7 million viewers #8221; over the three major English language broadcast networks and three leading cable news channels. Relatively few people, it turns out, want to subject themselves to monotonous speeches delivered at high decibels. There is nothing new here #8212; no surprise or metamorphosis in the GOP #8217;s thinking. Pace yourself: You #8217;ll need to husband all that emotional ballast for November, when Trump inevitably refuses to accept the result of the election."

WRITING.TITLE: When will Trump be held responsible for the horrors he creates?

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "While the national media debates whether Americans care about the Hatch Act (Hint: It doesn #8217;t matter; journalists #8217; task is to inform the public), the gap between Republicans and reality widens. The Republican National Convention is attempting to convince us that President Trump has heroically addressed the coronavirus pandemic, outdone President Barack Obama on the economy, cares about immigrants and leads a party that is welcoming to Blacks. In the real world, the pandemic is still out of control, much of the economy and many schools remains shuttered, and anti-Black and anti-immigrant sentiment is rising. Only one presidential candidate is deploring another shooting of an unarmed Black American and denouncing violence: [video of Biden denouncing violence and looting.] Meanwhile, Trump sounds the law-and-order horn (despite a slew of his own aides arrested or convicted of crimes, a bonanza of Hatch Act violations, an incitement for cops to mistreat suspects and multiple investigations into Trump #8217;s own finances). He blames racial violence in our cities on liberals and Black Lives Matter protesters. In fact, we should look to systemic racism and police indifference. The Associated Press reports: - A white, 17-year-old police admirer was arrested Wednesday after two people were shot to death during a third straight night of protests in Kenosha over the police shooting of a Black man, Jacob Blake. - Kyle Rittenhouse, of Antioch, Illinois, was taken into custody in Illinois on suspicion of first-degree intentional homicide. Antioch is about 15 miles from Kenosha. . . . - According to witness accounts and video footage, police apparently let the young man responsible for the shootings walk past them with a rifle over his shoulder with his hands in the air as members of the crowd were yelling for him to be arrested because he had shot people. Rittenhouse #8217;s social media entries feature #8220;Blue Lives Matter #8221; tributes, the slogan Republicans widely use to rebut efforts to focus on the plague of killings of Black men. Police at the protests also seem to have encouraged armed vigilantes. The Associated Press reports: #8220;Video taken before the shooting showed police tossing bottled water from an armored vehicle to what appear to be armed civilians walking the streets. And one of them appears to be the gunman. #8216;We appreciate you being here, #8217; an officer is heard saying to the group over a loudspeaker. #8221; What is striking about the dishonest messaging from Trump and his fellow Republicans, which has surely fueled this atmosphere, is that the media #8217;s focus has been on whether it will work or convince voters. There are two problems with such takes. First, the answers are unknowable. There is no polling which tells us one way or another. However, the focus on these questions makes politics into a value-free, fact-free game. The message to voters implicitly says that what matters in politics is whether a candidate #8217;s message resonates with his or her base. Instead, the focus should be on what is happening in the country (e.g., a Category 4 hurricane bearing down on the Gulf Coast with no mention from the president, a pandemic out of control, another example of systemic racism in policing) and the abject dishonesty of a party unwilling to accept reality or responsibility. Second, the media ignores the degree to which Republicans contribute to racial injustice by refusing to acknowledge it exists. Robert P. Jones of PRRI explains: Messaging from the Republican convention is clearly an effort to capitalize on racial violence. After all the protests, all the heartfelt efforts to diversify newsrooms to improve coverage and the deaths of so many Black Americans, how is it possible that the coverage is so frivolous and the lack of accountability so great? While the Republican convention has given Jacob Blake #8217;s shooting short shrift, the National Basketball Association postponed Wednesday #8217;s schedule of playoff games after Milwaukee Bucks team members refused to take the court for their game earlier in the afternoon. Maybe the NBA can give the event the attention it deserves. We face the most consequential election in our lifetimes. One party is brazenly displaying its ability to bamboozle its base. It behooves the rest of us not to praise their ingenuity, but to refocus on the three major crises we face: a health crisis unprecedented over the last 100 years, an economic collapse equivalent to the Great Depression, and a spate of racial violence against unarmed Black people, each of which the sitting president waves off while spinning a false narrative of Democrats #8217; #8220;socialism #8221; and indifference to violence."

WRITING.TITLE: The five dumbest Republican arguments for Trump

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "None of Republicans #8217; commonly deployed arguments for reelecting President Trump are tethered to reality. The paucity of logic and factual support for their rationales suggests many on the right, even #8220;respectable #8221; columnists and elected officials, actually support him for reasons they #8217;re loath to admit, whether it #8217;s because they share his apocalyptic view of crime encroaching on the suburbs or are eager to see a country purged of immigrants. He will give us law and order: If public safety is the concern, the unnecessary deaths from covid-19, which might exceed 200,000 by Election Day, and the anxiety over leaving our homes for fear of joining 6 million infected Americans surely make Trump #8217;s tenure the most dangerous for ordinary Americans. Each week, we have been losing twice the number of Americans killed on Sept. 11. No wonder Trump loves to highlight any domestic scene of disorder, mayhem and looting he can to frighten White Americans, arguing that if law enforcement #8220;dominates the streets, #8221; we will have public order. This is preposterous. We cannot go to war with millions of demonstrators. That #8217;s simply impossible, not to mention morally objectionable. The demands of the protesters, among them police reform and voting rights legislation are entirely legitimate. But so long as Trump denies the legitimacy of these concerns and the presence of systemic racism, we will not have domestic tranquility. Trump celebrates violence, encourages police misconduct, honors Whites indicted for brandishing guns at marchers and tear-gassed peaceful protesters in Lafayette Square. Senior adviser Kellyanne Conway let on that the administration believes that the more violence happens in the streets, the better chance Trump has of being reelected. Meanwhile, Trump smears our intelligence community, spinning false conspiracy theories and adopting Vladimir Putin #8217;s version of the 2016 plot to interfere with our election. Trump tramples on laws and precedents ranging from the Hatch Act to turning over his tax returns to the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee upon request. There is no president in recent memory who has hired and associated with so many convicted felons. He personally is under investigation by multiple authorities for potential financial crimes. He is his own crime spree. As President Trump threatens to unleash the military on American cities roiled in civil unrest, it's clear that he's embracing his inner Nixon. (Joshua Carroll, Kate Woodsome/The Washington Post) He has vanquished the pandemic: The level of delusion necessary to sustain the fiction that Trump has handled the pandemic well is unfathomable. We have more deaths due to the disease than any other country on the planet, many more deaths per capita than many advanced countries and no national testing-and-tracing program. We remain cloistered at home and children cannot attend school in person in most places after weeks of shutdowns, largely because Trumped egged officials into reopening prematurely. He has hawked dangerous and unproven remedies and pressured government health experts to weaken or change guidelines to minimize dangers and restrictions on activities. As he did Thursday night, he gathers large crowds without masks and social distancing, creating his very own potential superspreading events. He has been great for the economy: Multiple fact-checkers have repeatedly demonstrated that the economy under President Barack Obama #8217;s was stronger by multiple measures than the economy under Trump. This disparity was due in part to tariffs Trump imposed, which amount to a tax hike for U.S. consumers. If Trump falsely thinks he inherited a rotten economy, it #8217;s inarguable that it got worse even before he crashed it by attempting to ignore a pandemic. It is now evident that some jobs lost will not return when #8212; and if #8212; the coronavirus is vanquished. Hundreds, if not thousands, of businesses have closed. Companies will not all emerge from bankruptcy. Trump ends his four years with record unemployment and debt #8212; and without a plan to reduce either. Joe Biden is a socialist: Not even the Republicans have the nerve to make that argument. Instead, they argue that Biden will be tricked or led around by the nose by forces on the left. This is entirely speculative and ignores Biden #8217;s decades-long record in office (remember the 1994 crime bill?) and policy choices during the campaign, among them his opposition to Medicare-for-all. Moreover, we have yet to see in American politics a situation in which the wing of a party defeated in the presidential primary magically controls the executive branch after their rivals from the same party assume office. Moreover, if #8220;conservatives #8221; are worried about the expansion of government, then Trump #8217;s widespread abuse of executive power, meddling in investigations and enforcement actions to benefit cronies and punish enemies, threats to harm certain companies (as in his call for a boycott of Goodyear), protectionism and capitulation to illiberal regimes, as well as the mammoth debt he #8217;s run up, his indiscriminate use of federal forces against protesters, his misuse of government property and government employees to serve his personal interests, and attacks on the courts and free press make Trump the least conservative president ever (if that word has any meaning anymore). #8220;Life #8221;: One can respect those deeply opposed to abortion in evaluating the candidates, but by the same token, a president who prioritizes the economy over preventing a pandemic, rips children from the arms of their mothers, refuses to denounce killings of unarmed Black Americans and willfully declines to protect the lives of our troops on whose heads Russia placed bounties is not respectful of human life in any meaningful sense. Indeed, Trump has turned the party into a vicious death cult that trivializes the nearly 180,000 deaths caused by covid-19 to date. When you create superspreader crowds to soothe your ego, you are endangering human life. When one party willfully ignores a pandemic and treats Black lives as expendable, it loses any moral authority regarding the sanctity of human life. In refusing to be guided by scientific facts (be it on air and water quality, climate change or covid-19), Trump puts at risk the health and lives of millions of people."

WRITING.TITLE: How Has Donald Trump Survived?

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: (shortened for length): "When a Republican-led Senate committee issued a nearly 1,000-page report in mid-August that detailed the prodigious extent of the contacts between Russian officials and members of Donald Trump #8217;s 2016 campaign team, it felt a bit like a dispatch from a vaguely familiar reality #8212; a prepandemic realm when we could mostly agree to focus on foreign interference in American democracy, and when the Trump presidency felt as if it were hanging in the balance while it awaited word from Robert S. Mueller III. This is the world that forged Michael S. Schmidt #8217;s #8220;Donald Trump v. the United States. #8221; It vividly resurrects that actually-not-so-distant era by unspooling the occasionally staggering stories of two administration figures who were central to the investigative sagas that dominated the early Trump years, largely thanks to their attempts to constrain him. The subjects are both all too familiar and, Schmidt implies, underappreciated in their significance in shaping Trump #8217;s presidency. Schmidt recounts with unsparing intimacy James Comey #8217;s arc from the 2016 election to his 2017 firing from the F.B.I. directorship, and he documents the relentlessly uncomfortable White House tenure of the former general counsel Donald F. McGahn II, who, he points out, #8220;was in charge of Trump #8217;s greatest political accomplishment, and he found himself caught up as the chief witness against Trump. #8221; The result is a revelatory portrait of the events that led to the investigation of Trump for obstruction of justice, and his repeated attempts to control the Department of Justice. It is not about the alleged collusion with Moscow, and in fact Schmidt reports that Mueller #8217;s investigators #8220;never undertook a significant examination of Trump #8217;s personal and business ties to Russia, #8221; largely thanks to the deputy attorney general Rod Rosenstein #8217;s intervention. Schmidt, a New York Times correspondent in Washington who was part of two teams that won Pulitzer Prizes in 2018, including one for coverage of Trump #8217;s Russian-inflected scandals, portrays an administration in which all aides may as well always have a resignation letter ready as a safeguard against an angry, flailing president detached from commonly accepted reality. This is a meticulously reported volume that clearly benefits from the author #8217;s extraordinary access to many of the relevant characters, but also from his subjects #8217; tendency to record, in detail, their time around Trump. Whereas recent years have been packed with high-impact reported books about Trump #8217;s erratic behavior and his administration #8217;s backbiting #8212; Bob Woodward #8217;s #8220;Fear, #8221; Philip Rucker and Carol Leonnig #8217;s #8220;A Very Stable Genius #8221; and Jonathan Karl #8217;s #8220;Front Row at the Trump Show #8221; come to mind #8212; #8220;Donald Trump v. the United States #8221; is more closely tailored to the efforts to rein Trump in. As such, it may be unlikely to become a go-to for general conclusions about Trump #8217;s character. But it adds significantly to the public understanding of the Mueller investigation and Trump #8217;s war against it. The narrative is sometimes cinematic. It opens with Schmidt chasing down McGahn outside the White House #8217;s front gates and eventually getting him to concede, #8220;I damaged the office of the president; I damaged the office. #8221; It #8217;s a breathtakingly revealing admission from the White House #8217;s chief lawyer and the architect of Trump #8217;s effort to appoint as many conservative judges as possible. (Schmidt says, #8220;I thought he was still understating the gravity of what he had done. #8221;) McGahn, a staunch libertarian, was frequently in over his head with the lawless president he nicknamed #8220;King Kong, #8221; and he struggled with his highly unusual extended contact with Mueller #8217;s team. Still, despite getting close to resigning, McGahn stuck around far longer than his apparent misery and frequent attempts at principled stands would suggest, largely because of his judicial project #8217;s success. It was only after Trump granted a woman clemency at Kim Kardashian #8217;s request that McGahn knew he truly had to leave the White House. He could no longer abide the accumulation of Trump #8217;s actions. Then, in the annals of unsustainable relationships with Trump, there #8217;s James Comey. His early interactions with the president, like the one-on-one dinner at which Trump requested Comey #8217;s loyalty, have been described repeatedly. But in Schmidt #8217;s granular telling, the relationship was especially agonizing because of a fundamental disconnect between the two men. Comey was always deeply interested in maintaining his and his agency #8217;s public credibility #8212; especially after his wildly controversial intrusions into the 2016 campaign over Hillary Clinton #8217;s emails. After he was fired by Trump, he text-messaged a friend: #8220;I #8217;m with my peeps (former peeps). They are broken up and I #8217;m sitting with them like a wake. Trying to figure out how to get back home. May hitchhike. #8221; It #8217;s just one example of the clearly extensive access Schmidt had to Comey and his wife. #8220;Donald Trump v. the United States #8221; is full of gritty details about what it #8217;s like for a plugged-in journalist to report on Trump #8217;s intrigue, ranging from the time Schmidt shepherded a valued source to and from the airport, to his learning, secondhand, about a Justice Department official soliciting dirt on Comey at a Cinco de Mayo party. At one point, Schmidt writes, he shattered his cellphone and didn #8217;t fix it for a week because there was too much news; he ended up with pieces of glass in his hands. More interesting, however, is the constant flow of shocking anecdotes: Schmidt writes that Mitch McConnell fell asleep during a classified briefing on Russia, for example, and he details the F.B.I. #8217;s shambolic reaction to evidence of the hacking in 2016, including an unresolved disagreement over how to handle the material. Describing Trump #8217;s unexpected November 2019 visit to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, he reports the White House wanted Mike Pence #8220;on standby to take over the powers of the presidency temporarily if Trump had to undergo a procedure that would have required him to be anesthetized. #8221; (The vice president never had to take this step.)"

WRITING.TITLE: This isn #8217;t an administration. It #8217;s an ongoing criminal conspiracy.

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "It is entirely fitting that Donald Trump #8212; the least law-abiding president in our history #8212; was renominated at a convention that was itself a seeming cavalcade of crime. Every night featured apparent violations of the 1939 Hatch Act, which prohibits federal employees from engaging in political activities #8220;in any room or building occupied in the discharge of official duties by an individual employed or holding office in the Government of the United States. #8221; The White House certainly qualifies as such a facility. Yet Trump used it as a convention prop, even going so far as to televise a naturalization ceremony for immigrants #8212; some of whom did not realize they would be shown at the Republican convention #8212; as part of the nightly show. Trump not only flouted the law but also reveled in doing so. During his acceptance speech, he boasted, #8220;We #8217;re here #8212; they #8217;re not, #8221; and the New York Times reported that Trump #8220;relished the fact that no one could do anything to stop him. #8221; While the president is exempt from the civil provisions of the Hatch Act, he could be subject, once he leaves office, to criminal penalties if he should #8220;intimidate, threaten, command, or coerce #8230; any employee of the Federal Government #8230; to engage in #8230; any political activity. #8221; That is a crime punishable by up to three years in prison. This is, of course, barely scratching the surface of an administration that should more accurately be described as an ongoing criminal conspiracy. While many of Trump #8217;s awful acts #8212; e.g., confining children in cages or unleashing riot police on peaceful protesters #8212; are merely violations of democratic norms, there is also plentiful evidence of lawbreaking on his part. The U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York has identified Trump as #8220;Individual-1 #8221; in a conspiracy with his attorney Michael Cohen to violate campaign finance laws by secretly paying off two women with whom he allegedly had affairs. Cohen went to prison; Trump, who as president claims immunity from prosecution, wasn #8217;t indicted. Special counsel Robert S. Mueller III uncovered a great deal more potential illegality. He found 10 instances when Trump might have obstructed justice, and in at least four of those cases he found evidence that Trump #8217;s conduct met all three elements of the obstruction-of-justice statute. Each violation carries a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison. The recent report from the Senate Intelligence Committee suggests that Trump also lied to Mueller when, in written testimony, he claimed not to remember speaking to Roger Stone about WikiLeaks. If he committed perjury, that would subject him to up to five years #8217; imprisonment. Trump #8217;s impeachment, on charges of trying to extort Ukraine into helping him politically, uncovered more conduct that could be criminal. Just Security published an invaluable compendium written by eminent legal experts who argued that Trump might have broken federal campaign finance laws (he solicited something of value from a foreign national), bribery laws, the #8220;honest services #8221; law ( #8220;a public official breaches his duty to act in the best interests of his constituents by performing an official acting in exchange for personal gain #8221;), the contempt-of-Congress law #8212; and, yet again, the Hatch Act, which prohibits a public official from using #8220;official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election. #8221; Then there all the financial crimes Trump might be hiding by refusing to release his tax returns and other financial documents. The Manhattan district attorney and the New York attorney general are said to be investigating Trump for potential campaign finance violations, bank fraud and tax fraud. The question is: Who will investigate Trump #8217;s potentially illegal conduct while in office #8212; and prosecute him, if warranted, once he leaves it? We know it won #8217;t be Attorney General William P. Barr, Trump #8217;s accomplice in perverting the Constitution. That means it will be up to Joe Biden, assuming he wins in November. In the past, I would have argued for leaving Trump alone after he steps down so as to end our #8220;long national nightmare. #8221; But now I am convinced that Trump #8217;s wrongdoing is so pervasive and brazen that he must be prosecuted to uphold the rule of law and deter even greater lawbreaking by future presidents. If elected, President Biden should appoint a special counsel of unimpeachable integrity #8212; a widely respected former U.S. attorney or federal judge #8212; with a wide-ranging mandate to investigate Trump and his administration. That prosecutor should finally summon Trump to testify orally under oath or assert his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination #8212; something Mueller never did. If Trump did testify, it would almost certainly result in perjury charges. Trump could try to short-circuit justice by trying to pardon himself before he leaves office #8212; or even by resigning a few hours early and having Vice President Pence sworn in to issue a pardon (as President Gerald Ford did for Richard Nixon). In that case, the special counsel would be limited to investigating Trump #8217;s accomplices (unless they are also pardoned) and helping state prosecutors. But the special counsel should still issue a comprehensive report on Trump #8217;s lawbreaking. We must expose and root out this ethical rot before it eats away at the foundations of our democracy."

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "President Trump, during an interview on Monday with Fox News #8217;s Laura Ingraham, a spin artist for the president and a purveyor of anti-immigrant sentiment, claimed that Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden is controlled by mysterious people. (Disclaimer: I am an MSNBC contributor.) In concocting his tale, Trump fantasized of #8220;people that you #8217;ve never heard of, people that are in the dark shadows. #8221; Ingraham, as though trying her best to stop his self-immolation, responded, #8220;That sounds like conspiracy theory. #8221; No luck. Trump continued: #8220;They are people that are on the streets, they #8217;re people that are controlling the streets. We had somebody get on a plane from a certain city this weekend. And in the plane, it was almost completely loaded with thugs, wearing these dark uniforms, black uniforms, with gear and this and that. #8221; This is simply bonkers. Ingraham then stopped him from digging himself a deeper hole when he suggested police who kill unarmed people are akin to a golfer missing a three-foot putt. #8220;But they choke, just like in a golf tournament, they miss a three-foot [putt], #8221; Trump said. Ingraham leaped in: #8220;You #8217;re not comparing it to golf, because that #8217;s what the media [would say]. #8221; In other words, actual reporters would recognize what he was saying was morally offensive and so lacking in self-awareness as to suggest Trump cannot even fake normal behavior. Trump had no one around him on Tuesday to stage an intervention, so he repeated his gibberish: "A person was on a plane, said there were about six people like that person, more or less, and what happened is the entire plane filled up with the looters, the anarchists, rioters #8212; people that were obviously looking for trouble, #8221; Trump insisted. #8220;And the person felt very uncomfortable on the plane. #8221; He added: "This would be a person you know. So I will see whether or not I can get that person. I #8217;ll let them know, and I can see whether or not I can get that person to speak to you, #8221; he said. #8220;This was a firsthand account of a plane going from Washington to wherever. #8221; #8220;Wherever #8221; is the sort of filler you use when your lie becomes too absurd to add anymore detail. The unparalleled Daniel Dale from CNN dubbed Trump #8217;s people-on-the-plane story as #8220;almost too stupid to fact-check, #8221; before issuing a reminder that Trump is infamous for his unfounded and bizarre conspiracy theories (e.g., former president Barack Obama wasn #8217;t born in America; windmills cause cancer). In a normal time, with a functioning Republican Party and a patriotic vice president, this might be the end of Trump #8217;s campaign and an invitation to invoke the 25th Amendment. We, unfortunately, have spineless sycophants in the GOP and a zombie-like vice president who feels compelled to show allegiance to a president plainly unfit to hold office. Likewise, in most families, there would be a family meeting to stop him from embarrassing himself. (Perhaps not in families where its members stand to inherit millions of dollars.) No chance of that, but the thesis from the president #8217;s niece, Mary Trump, that there is something seriously wrong with him looks pretty unassailable. Surely, some excuse will emerge. Maybe Trump was #8220;just joking." Maybe Republicans will actually insist the president was telling the truth, making them also sound like they #8217;ve also gone around the bend. The real sin here is the right-wing media that keep protecting Trump, the pundits who will argue it does not matter what he says, and the Republicans too timid to stand up to someone incapable of doing the job. It does not help that the mainstream media pulls its punches. Something is really, really wrong #8212; and those pretending that it is not are endangering the country and our democracy."
I thought it was something he sort of remembered (and transferred) from a briefing on Erik Prince's activities.

WRITING.TITLE: Debate moderators shouldn #8217;t be afraid to ask Trump embarrassing questions

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "The first presidential debate is scheduled to take place in four weeks. Moderators should be preparing themselves to ask President Trump the questions that go to the heart of his ability to do his job #8212; even if he gets upset, and even though no president has had to answer similar questions before. Here are a few: - There is no scientific evidence windmills cause cancer. Why did you say they do? - You said forces in the #8220;dark shadows #8221; control your opponent and that a pack of figures in dark clothing with gear were reported on a plane. Is there any factual support for this? What flight were you talking about, and how would anyone know that those people on the plane are out to manipulate the former vice president? - You keep saying President Barack Obama spied on you and your 2016 campaign. The bipartisan Senate Intelligence Committee said that this is false. No Justice Department investigation has found this. No evidence has been made publicly available. On what basis do you say your predecessor acted illegally? - You said under oath in written answers that you couldn #8217;t remember whether you spoke to others on your 2016 campaign about WikiLeaks #8217;s release of hacked emails from the Democratic National Committee (DNC). In fact, Roger Stone spoke to you about the email dump on July 25, 2016, according to the testimony of former campaign adviser Rick Gates. Did you forget this conversation? - There is zero evidence that Ukraine interfered with the 2016 election or that the DNC server is there. That claim is Russian propaganda. Why did you repeat these assertions over and over again? - When have you ever publicly criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin? Is he a dictator? Does Russia kill journalists and Putin #8217;s opponents? - Why did you want to let Russia back into the Group of Seven; repeat Russian propaganda that the Soviet Union was engaged in a defensive war in Afghanistan in the 1980s; refuse to confront Putin on the evidence of Russian bounties on U.S. soldiers (even after it became public knowledge); and insist you were not briefed on the Russian bounties even though it appeared in your written briefing in late February? - The United States has lost more than 181,000 people to covid-19, more than any country in the world and more than many Western countries on a per-capita basis. No other country has been at least partially shut down or hobbled for six months, or has failed to institute a national testing-and-tracing plan. Was your handling of the virus a #8220;success #8221;? - When you said the United States had 15 positive cases of the novel coronavirus and then claimed the disease would disappear, you were wrong. Why did you assure Americans the number of cases would soon be #8220;zero #8221;? - Why do you want to keep the names men who betrayed the United States by taking up arms against the Union during the Civil War on military bases? Do you believe the South fought the Civil War to preserve slavery? Do you disagree that the Confederate flag is meant to lionize those men? - President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act, the Voting Rights Act and the 1968 Fair Housing Act. Other presidents have appointed Black judges to the Supreme Court or at least to federal appellate courts, which you have not. Other presidents have had multiple African Americans in their Cabinet; you have one. How can you say you did more for Blacks than any other president since Abraham Lincoln? - Why have you not condemned the police shooting of Jacob Blake? Why did you offer a defense of the White man who allegedly killed two people in Kenosha, Wis.? - You said you do not want higher levels of voting. Isn #8217;t that the opposite of democracy? - Before the pandemic hit, the economy under your presidency created fewer jobs on average per month than during the last three years of the Obama administration. All three of his final years in office beat your best year of growth. Why do you say you inherited a bad economy? - You said the economy would grow by 4 percent or more under the 2017 tax cuts and that they would result in no new debt. Neither happened. Why were you so far off in your prediction? - Who pays for tariffs? What is the #8220;trade deficit #8221;? - You said you would protect people with preexisting conditions, but you are in court seeking to repeal all of Obamacare, including that protection. Can you explain the contradiction? - Why did you unexpectedly go to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center last November? Why were you administered a basic test for dementia and similar conditions? How many times have you taken such a test? Was Vice President Pence put on alert when you went to Walter Reed? Has any doctor examined you for impaired mental ability or for physical conditions from such impairment?"

WRITING.TITLE: Nothing has turned around for Trump

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "President Trump, it seems, was counting on the fantasyland production at the White House for the Republican National Convention to change the trajectory of the race. It did not happen, and with less than nine weeks to go before Election Day, and much less before early voting gets underway, the post-convention momentum is going in the other direction. Start with the money. The Biden campaign #8217;s jaw-dropping, unprecedented blizzard of more than $364 million in donations for the month of August #8212; with 95 percent coming from #8220;grassroots supporters #8221; (1.5 million of the total 4 million donors gave for the first time last month) and 57 percent coming from online #8212; gives former vice president Joe Biden all the money he needs for the final stretch."Moreover, the outpouring of support and number of small donors are an indication of excitement for a candidate who was supposed to have difficulty with online fundraising and a less-than-enthusiastic base. The reason may be simple: Sen. Kamala D. Harris (D-Calif.), whose selection as Biden #8217;s running mate drove an outpouring of support in the days following the announcement. Trump #8217;s entire effort over the past couple of weeks has been an effort to paint the Democratic nominee as enfeebled and himself as the law-and-order candidate. Instead, Trump is having trouble fending off the perception he is off his rocker, as the latest Lincoln Project ad suggests: [Lincoln Project video] On the law-and-order side, Biden effectively flipped the script this way by reminding Americans that the violence has taken place in Trump #8217;s America and that Trump has incited violence. The Biden campaign thinks this is a compelling message: [Biden ad] Moreover, Biden continues to lead Trump in polling on the law-and-order issue. A new Morning Consult-Politico poll reported on Wednesday that "47 percent of voters said they trust Biden more to handle public safety, compared to 39 percent who said they place more trust in Trump. The president #8217;s deficit on safety #8212; one of many issues on which Biden is more trusted #8212; comes as Trump has sought to portray the former vice president as a danger to voters #8217; personal security in advertising, on Twitter and perhaps most prominently during his Aug. 27 address from the Republican National Convention. #8221; This might explain why Biden feels confident in going to Kenosha, Wis., on Thursday; rather than avoid the law-and-order issue, he seems to be saying, #8220;Bring it on. #8221; Biden has a 7.5 percent national lead in the FiveThirtyEight average, a tick down from a peak of about 9 points. Even still, he has remained remarkably steady since June. He maintains leads in battleground states such as Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Arizona, Florida, Wisconsin and New Hampshire. Based on current polling, Biden has more than enough to surpass 270 electoral votes needed to win. The race could certainly change in nine weeks, although none of the recent events seems to have recast the race. The conventions are over; the debates remain. The Commission on Presidential Debates announced the moderators for the three presidential debates #8212; Fox News #8217;s Chris Wallace (who made mincemeat of Trump in their last interview), CSPAN #8217;s Steve Scully and NBC News #8217;s Kristen Welker. It is far from certain that Trump can maintain his a-factual, conspiracy-laden mind-set with an aggressive opponent and unflinching moderator #8212; although there is plenty of research to suggest debates do not change voters #8217; minds. As for real-world conditions, we do know that coronavirus deaths will continue to rise and that unemployment will remain quite high by historic standards. No wonder Trump seems increasingly frantic and inclined to spew outlandish conspiracy theories."
If they're reasonable and don't lie, yes. But that's generally a big if.

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "I never want to hear President Trump whine about phony accounts of voter fraud again. On Wednesday, he suggested North Carolina voters should test their vote-by-mail system, thereby committing what amounts to voter fraud. #8220;Let them send it in and let them go vote, and if their system #8217;s as good as they say it is, then obviously they won #8217;t be able to vote," Trump said. "If it isn #8217;t tabulated, they #8217;ll be able to vote. #8221; This would be illegal #8212; and obviously so. Attorney General William P. Barr pleaded ignorance on Wednesday as to whether voting twice is a crime and also ducked a question from CNN #8217;s Wolf Blitzer about how many actual voter fraud claims the feds have pursued. (Hint: Hardly any.) Trump and his enablers have gone from making up claims of voter fraud to countenancing and encouraging it. I never want to hear Republicans complain about the debt again. The Post reports, #8220;For the first time since World War II, the U.S. government #8217;s debt will roughly equal the size of the entire American economy by the end of this year, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said Wednesday. #8221; The numbers are eye-popping: #8220;By the end of 2020, the amount of debt owed by the United States will amount to 98 percent of the nation #8217;s gross domestic product, the CBO said. That is up from 79 percent last year. Total government debt will surpass the U.S. economy #8217;s size next year, the CBO said. #8221; If Democrats win control of the government in November, why shouldn #8217;t they feel free to spend with the same abandon Republicans have? I never want to hear Republicans claim the #8220;law and order #8221; mantle again. They have supported a president who glorifies violent White militias. They sneer at lawful subpoenas, the emoluments clause and the Hatch Act. No administration since Richard Nixon #8217;s has had more presidential associates and staffers indicted (and convicted). No Senate Republican gets to complain about the qualities of a Democrat #8217;s nominees after Trump nominated nine judges rated #8220;unqualified #8221; by the American Bar Association and put a flock of inexperienced and unqualified people in executive posts (e.g., Rex Tillerson, Matthew Whitaker, Jared Kushner, Ivanka Trump, Kathy Kraninger, Richard Grenell). Republicans have also lost the credibility to complain about executive overreach after they countenanced Trump #8217;s efforts to snatch funds from the military to pay for the border wall, to deploy unmarked federal troops to states without consent of governors and to assert #8220;absolute immunity #8221; from subpoenas. And now that a Republican president has unilaterally sought to yank funds from #8220;anarchist jurisdictions #8221; and from cities that refused to allow local law enforcement to be dragooned into performing federal immigration enforcement #8212; not to mention Trump #8217;s attempt to prevent states from setting higher regulatory standards #8212; Republicans do not get to waive the 10th Amendment flag when it suits their fancy. No more moaning about taxpayer-funded family trips or golf time. No more criticism of executive branch turnover. Of course, just because Trump urged illegal conduct, encouraged voter fraud, ran up mammoth debt, associated with criminals, put incompetent cronies in top jobs, trashed the separations of powers and bilked the taxpayers does not mean Democrats should do the same. It does, however, mean that Republicans have lost the credibility to govern or to obstruct based on principles they abandoned during Trump #8217;s tenure."

WRITING.TITLE: Trump #8217;s bad marriage with the military has finally exploded

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: by David Ignatius "Reconciling Donald Trump #8217;s self-promoting #8220;Art of the Deal #8221; with the military #8217;s reserved code of loyalty and service was always a stretch. In Trump #8217;s early months in the White House, though, the two cultures seemed to coexist without much damage. But the fabric began to fray by mid-2017. Trump increasingly treated the military as props in the reality-TV show of his presidency. He wanted them for parades and victory celebrations, not the anguish of combat. He seemed to take his strategic guidance from Fox News more than his commanders. The generals and admirals kept their mouths shut, but the resentment was building. The bad marriage exploded this week, when former senior staff members told Jeffrey Goldberg of the Atlantic of their shock at Trump #8217;s crude comments about combat and loss #8212; and his reported characterization of fallen warriors as #8220;suckers #8221; and #8220;losers. #8221; The quotes were anonymous, but it has been an open secret in Washington that many prominent retired four-stars have regarded Trump with growing horror as he assaulted the traditions of discipline and professionalism that are bedrocks of military life. The first open break point came in June, after former military leaders watched Trump try to use the military to put down protests for racial justice. Retired Adm. Mike Mullen, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, denounced Trump for #8220;politicizing the men and women of our armed forces. #8221; Retired Gen. Jim Mattis, the former defense secretary, called Trump #8220;the first president in my lifetime who does not try to unite the American people. #8221; Retired Gen. John F. Kelly, a former Trump White House chief of staff, said he agreed with Mattis. It #8217;s hard to remember now that Trump #8217;s dealings with military leaders started off pretty well. I remember traveling in May 2017 with our Special Operations forces to the newly liberated town of Tabqa, at the gates of the Islamic State #8217;s capital of Raqqa. A senior U.S. official told the Syrian Kurdish commander who led the assault that this rapid assault #8220;never would have happened without Donald Trump. #8221; There would have been too many meetings under his predecessor, President Barack Obama. Trump wanted victory in Afghanistan, too, so long as it was fast and unambiguous. Gen. John Nicholson, the U.S. commander in Kabul, was given authority to use America #8217;s most intimidating conventional weapon against the Taliban #8212; the so-called #8220;mother of all bombs. #8221; No more anguished meetings in the Situation Room. The gloves were off. Trump initially saw Mattis as a man in his own image #8212; awarding him the Trumpian nickname #8220;Mad Dog, #8221; even though the ascetic Mattis was closer to a monk than a mongrel. Over the two years Mattis ran the Pentagon, his relationship with Trump grew poisonous. The more Mattis tried to educate Trump, as in his widely reported July 2017 seminar in the #8220;tank #8221; at Pentagon, the more Trump became resentful. Trump berated his generals at that gathering #8212; with language that #8217;s eerily similar to what was reported in the Atlantic this week. According to Philip Rucker and Carol D. Leonnig in their book, #8220;A Very Stable Genius, #8221; Trump said: #8220;You #8217;re all losers. You don #8217;t know how to win anymore. #8221; Trump really did seem to think he knew better than his generals. #8220;I wouldn #8217;t go to war with you people, #8221; Trump told them, according to Rucker and Leonnig. #8220;You #8217;re a bunch of dopes and babies. #8221; The commander who succeeded best in keeping the lid on, as Trump grew cockier, was Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the chairman of the Joint Chiefs. A tall, reserved and utterly reliable Marine, he was often able to curb Trump #8217;s impulsive decisions and steer him toward steady policy, without infuriating him. What the military liked in Trump was that he was sometimes (not always) prepared to #8220;take the shot #8221; at terrorist adversaries, such as Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State, and Gen. Qasem Soleimani, the leader of Iran #8217;s Quds Force. Trump #8217;s near-constant belittling of NATO hurt his standing with the Pentagon. So did his inexplicable affinity for Russian President Vladimir Putin. Yet military leaders bit their lips, because they were grateful that Trump had endorsed a national military strategy that took a tougher stance toward Russia and China #8212; and added money for new weapons to combat these near-peer adversaries. A heartbreaker for the military was Trump #8217;s decision to abandon the Syrian Kurds who had fought so bravely against the Islamic State. I remember talking to the officer who had to break the news of Trump #8217;s decision to quit Syria to Gen. Mazloum Abdi, the commander of the Syrian Democratic Forces. His description of that betrayal was unprintable. What the military came to understand over the past four years is that, for all Trump #8217;s talk of patriotism, he truly is transactional. Throughout his career, he has always believed that loyalty was for chumps. That #8217;s why New York business executives told me back in early 2016 they had never wanted to do business with him. The military understand their role in a democracy. They have obeyed Trump as their commander in chief, even amid his tirades and insults. And they will continue to do so if he #8217;s reelected. But many of them won #8217;t like it: Trump just isn #8217;t a guy with whom you #8217;d want to share a foxhole."

WRITING.TITLE: What do the polls tell us?

WRITING.TEXT: TEXT: "The most noteworthy aspect of national and state polling is their consistency. According to FiveThirtyEight #8217;s national poll average, Democratic nominee Joe Biden leads by about 7 #189; points over President Trump. For months, no credible public poll has showed Trump winning. The vast majority of polls released recently show Biden with a high single-digit or low double-digit lead. In Michigan, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Florida and Arizona #8212; all states Trump won in 2016 #8212; polls uniformly show Biden with at least a small lead. In many surveys, he enjoys a comfortable high single-digit lead in Michigan and Wisconsin. Wisconsin is striking because that state has gained attention for violence in Kenosha and is therefore front and center in Trump #8217;s effort to spread White resentment, fear and anger toward Blacks. It has not worked. The CBS/YouGov poll released Sunday shows Biden has a 10-point advantage nationally and the same 10-point (49 to 39 percent) over Trump when it comes to calming violence. Meanwhile, #8220;the larger notion that violence could come to #8216;the suburbs #8217; finds little concern among those who actually reside in the suburbs, #8221; CBS News said. The overwhelming majority favors an approach to violence adopted by Biden. "[B]y more than two to one, voters feel the way to end them is to make police reforms and address discrimination, not to use law enforcement to punish protesters. Even the president #8217;s own backers aren #8217;t overly convinced the latter approach is better, #8221; the report said. Most calamitous for Trump, voters by a wide margin (55 to 45 percent) see the election as a referendum on his four years rather than what Trump (21 percent) or Biden (24 percent) propose going forward. On metrics such as cares about people (63 to 44 percent), temperament (59 to 37 percent) and intelligence (56 to 47 percent), Biden clobbers Trump. Far more voters (50 percent) blame Trump than credit him (33 percent) for the covid-19 response. In sum, Trump #8217;s law-and-order message does not work, because many more voters see him as inflaming the situation. His accusation that Biden is some weakling, incapable of keeping the peace, falters because voters overwhelmingly like Biden #8217;s approach and understand that a solution to the violence requires addressing the basic concerns of racial justice advocates. Instead of winning over new adherents, Trump #8217;s #8220;more cowbell #8221; approach #8212; ever more hysterical tweets, racist appeals and unhinged conspiracies #8212; hardens voters #8217; positions. That is tremendously helpful for Biden, who has seen his lead solidify, but terrible news for a president who trails nationally and is behind in polls in many swing states he won in 2016. It is entirely possible Biden will win back the three Rust Belt states Hillary Clinton lost in 2016 (Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania), sealing the electoral majority #8212; and then also pick up states such as Florida, North Carolina and Arizona. A word is in order about the reports from multiple outlets confirming Trump in private disparaged wounded and dead military personnel as #8220;suckers #8221; and #8220;losers. #8221; It may be that for a small segment of weak pro-Trump voters who were teetering on the edge of abandoning him, the report provided a decisive push in Biden #8217;s direction. Just as damaging for Trump and worse for his party, however, is the potential that despondent Republicans will not show up at all (and won #8217;t vote by mail since Trump #8212; falsely #8212; said that was rife with fraud). That not only spells disaster for Trump. It also means Republicans up and down the ticket may get swept away in a blue tide. That would be an appropriate penalty for enabling and rationalizing Trump #8217;s odious behavior. I recall Gabriel Sherman #8217;s report two months ago when he wrote: #8220;A Republican strategist close to Mitch McConnell told me that Republicans have Labor Day penciled in as the deadline for Trump to have turned things around. After that, he #8217;s on his own. #8221; It #8217;s Labor Day, and he hasn #8217;t turned it around. Your call, Republican incumbents."

AFAIK, mass includes potential energy. For example, when you turn on a flashlight, its mass is reduced because some of its potential energy is being released. Get in a sealed, mirrored box and turn on the flashlight, and the mass of the box will not go down, because the energy is still contained. In this atom, the potential energy is *negative,* because the particles have less energy when the bound state forms.
